screens.text: "Idrin has authorized me to present a new proposal. Allow us to hunt the Founders exclusively, and we will leave both the Xindi and the rest of the Dominion in peace."

responses.text: "What's so special about the Founders?"
"It's the Xindi who protest your hunt, not me."
"The Jem'Hadar and the Vorta will never allow it."

screens.text: "A prey which never looks or acts the same way... a prey able to adapt to any situation... it is the ultimate hunt."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "They answer to you. You are responsible for their actions."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Then they will become prey as well, of their own free will."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Well? Does this proposal please you? We are attempting to... compromise."

responses.text: "There is no proposal that could make me agree to this."
"That seems more reasonable. I'll speak with the Xindi."
"Attack the Dominion in full with my blessing."

intro.text: "The Hirogen are now attacking a Xindi civilian transport. They insist one of the Founders is on board, but I know nothing of this. You must defend us!"

screens.text: "Thank you, Captain. We couldn't risk telling the Xindi where our Founders had chosen to hide, especially THE Founder. She is grateful for your assistance."

responses.text: "We have our differences, but no one deserves to be prey."
"You need to be honest with the Xindi if you want their help."
"If I'd known she was onboard, I would have destroyed the ship myself."

screens.text: "These Hirogen are impressively single-minded, aren't they? It's a wonder they stopped hunting long enough to develop warp technology."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We see opportunity among the Xindi. Honesty would ruin all our plans."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Then we shall take care to ensure you never know where she is."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "In our defeat, the Founder has been a source of hope and inspiration to the Dominion. We cannot allow the Hirogen to kill her, even at the risk of the other Founders' lives. I hope you see the advantages of helping us."

responses.text: "I see the morality of it, and that's enough for me."
"The Xindi clearly do, no matter what I think...."
"I plan to let the Hirogen do what nature intended."

quests.name: The Verge of Destruction
quests.description: Commander Tucker of the NX-01 is threatened by a reactivated Delphic Expanse sphere. Save his ship to save his data!

intro.text: "I'm up the proverbial creek, Captain... studying a reactivated sphere in the Delphic Expanse when the gravimetric energy got to be too much for my ship. We have to stabilize it if we want any of the data I've collected!"

reward.name: Credits
reward.flavor: Credits are the galaxy's standard currency. Use Credits in the Time Portal to enlist crew members, build items, and more.

screens.text: "Appreciate the rescue. The Xindi seem to think the Foundersthose goo peopleare hiding on one of these spheres. I'm apparently the only one around who knows anything about them."

responses.text: "What have you determined? Are the Founders here?"
"What are these spheres, and how do they operate?"
"You should show more sensitivity towards them."

screens.text: "Oh, they're here. Not as 'shifty' as they'd like to think they are. Get it?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Near as we can tell, they're artificially-created. They work to reconfigure the space around them to make it habitable for a certain type of being. The rest is classified."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Sorry. The galaxy was a little more rough-and-tumble back in my day."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "These spheres are unpredictable. Only the crazy or desperate would make a home out of them. Whatever you think of these Foundersand I'm told we don't think muchwe've got to get them to leave."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I know the Founders are there, but they aren't answering any of my hails or other attempts to get their attention. I say we send an away team down and knock the old-fashioned way."

responses.text: "An excellent idea. I'll form a landing party."
"If only to make for a fair hunt...."
"Just remember who's in command here, Tucker."

quests.name: Surveying the Sphere
quests.description: Investigate the sphere as thoroughly as possible while attempting to locate the Female Changeling and any other Founders hiding here.

intro.text: "Some intense thermobaric distortions going on down there, not to mention all this temporal wackiness. Watch yourselves and the Founders, if you can find 'em."

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

reward.flavor: Credits are the galaxy's standard currency. Use Credits in the Time Portal to enlist crew members, build items, and more.

screens.text: "I will never forget the terror I felt at becoming prey. If a new era of war begins between the Dominion and the solids, you will have the Hirogen to thank."

responses.text: "You have to leave the sphere. It isn't safe."
"We're doing everything can to protect you."
"I would welcome the chance to defeat you again."

screens.text: "We possess far more understanding of this sphere and its capabilities than you. We will see all the spheres achieve their intended purpose."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Then you are even more primitive than we first assumed. We are a potential threat to your survival. You gain nothing by ensuring we survive."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Hirogen merely exemplify the threat to peace which all of you are capable of. There is no cure for the violent madness which you carry."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Xindi are the one race among your chaotic Federation who may have potential. They may be worthy of joining the Dominion. With their service and the spheres, we may be able to carve out a home in this wilderness."

responses.text: "By transforming Xindi space? They'll never agree...."
"Good riddance. You deserve each other."
"If I have to protect you from yourselves, I will."

intro.text: "This is Dominion territory now. You will leave the Founders to their work or be destroyed!"

screens.text: "I wasn't around for this Dominion War, but these Founders sound like people we shouldn't trust with astroforming technology. What happens now?"

responses.text: "The spheres belong to the Xindi. There's nothing we can do."
"We remove the Founders from the spheres by force."
"I don't see a problem here. We should learn to live together."

screens.text: "There's plenty we can do! The Xindi might be our allies now, but we fought a war against them. They've got weaknesses like anyone else."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Xindi won't cotton to that. Unless you're all right with starting a Federation civil war."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "What, you think they're just going to park their spheres in orbit once they've tilled up a nice patch of space for themselves?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I think we need to find out just what got the Xindi and the Dominion in bed together. There might be a diplomatic way out of this whole thing."

responses.text: "Agreed. I'll try to arrange a meeting...."
"My phaser and I hope that you're wrong."
"I think you're overreacting, but I am curious."

intro.text: "Diplomatic talks with the Xindi have more than stalled... they've put this ship in lockdown and are refusing to let us leave. We need a Starfleet extraction, preferably without doing too much damage."

screens.text: "Say anything negative about the Dominion, and the Xindi act as though you said it about them. They've become such good friends that the Xindi are seriously considering leaving the Federation and joining the Dominion!"

responses.text: "Have the Xindi forgotten about the Dominion War?"
"Maybe we just sent the wrong diplomat."
"Let them. The Federation doesn't need the Xindi."

screens.text: "Easy to forget when it never reached them."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Looks like the apple doesn't fall far from the tree."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I wasn't around for the Dominion War, but I did fight the Xindi. Trust me, we do not want them both as potential enemies."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Dominion's a dictatorship, with the Founders commanding the Vorta and the Vorta commanding the Jem'Hadar. They control the Jem'Hadar through drug addiction. And they'll do the same to the Xindiwe just need proof."

responses.text: "We'll find this proof, no matter what it takes."
"You're wrong. Losing the war's changed the Dominion."
"I still don't see any problem here...."

quests.name: Ostensible Proof
quests.description: Captain Archer is sure the Dominion plans to enslave the Xindi. Hold farce talks to distract the Dominion while you search their files!

intro.text: "It wouldn't be suspicious to initiate diplomatic talks with the Dominion, especially after how our talk with the Xindi went. I'll keep them busy while your away team tries to get into their computers."

reward.name: Credits
reward.flavor: Credits are the galaxy's standard currency. Use Credits in the Time Portal to enlist crew members, build items, and more.

screens.text: "The Dominion may not have picked up on your deception, but we know those talks were a farce. The question now is if we tell our Dominion allies."

responses.text: "We apologize. We're only trying to protect you."
"Why are you allies at all, after what they've done?"
"Go ahead, tell them. I dare you."

screens.text: "Then treat us as equals, adults, members of a federation."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "If your intention is to drive us out of the Federation, you're making great strides."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Like us, the Dominion is a collective of races, all working cooperatively towards a single goal. With our guidance, we believe they could shed the imbalances that currently exist in their society and become better."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The more hostility the Federation displays towards the Dominion, the more we sympathize with them. For the Xindi of the present, the war with humanity is ancient history, but I have not forgotten."

responses.text: "You're free to make your own decisions, of course."
"So, really, you and other past Xindi are the problem."
"The Dominion will treat you like slaves or worse."

quests.name: Back Into the Fold
quests.description: Help the Federation's efforts to dissuade the Xindi from leaving to join the Dominion.

intro.text: "The Federation is the biggest collective of different races working together towards a common goal in the known galaxy! If the Xindi have gone blind to that, we've got to remind them what we're all about."

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

screens.text: "It's clear the Federation is trying to get our attention, if nothing else. Tell mewhat finally convinces my people to join you? Why should they remain with you now?"

responses.text: "We're a bigger and better version of the Dominion."
"That's a question only you and the Xindi can answer."
"I think you should leave the Federation. Was that not clear?"

screens.text: "Bigger, certainly. Better... that remains to be seen." He ends communications.

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Just so. We'll remember your respect." He ends communications.

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Abundantly." He ends communications.

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "So much has changed since my time. But I suppose that's true for everyone, no matter what timeline they're from. Whatever happens, thank you for helping to shed some light on this."

responses.text: "The Xindi are no longer our enemies. We should keep it that way."
"Whatever the Xindi decide, I hope it turns out well for them."
"Don't ask me to help these traitors again."

quests.name: Uprising
quests.description: A rebellious group of Jem'Hadar have turned on both the Founders and the Xindi. Protect at least the Xindi from coming to harm!

intro.text: "Rogue Jem'Hadar threaten both the Founders and your Xindi who shelter them. Join forces with us, and crush this rebellion in its infancy."

reward.name: Credits
reward.flavor: Credits are the galaxy's standard currency. Use Credits in the Time Portal to enlist crew members, build items, and more.

screens.text: "These creatures who break their oaths of loyalty are not fit to be called Jem'Hadar. They rebel against the natural order. They wish to hunt the Founders as the Hirogen do. Disgusting."

responses.text: "But why rebel now? What are their complaints?"
"Won't they quickly die without ketracel-white?"
"Personally, I admire them. You're being oppressed."

screens.text: "They believe the Hirogen will win. They say we are slaves to the Founders. Are all beings slaves to their gods, then?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Yes. Our battle strategy against them depends on it."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "No human will ever understand the ties that bind the Dominion together."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "There are many young among the rebels. I would not cut them down so swiftly. We will show them first the error of their ways, the brutality of life without the Founders."

responses.text: "I applaud your attempts at diplomacy first."
"They're going to die either way for attacking the Federation."
"I doubt they'll see much difference."

quests.name: Feed A Fever
quests.description: Help Remata'Klan convince the rebel Jem'Hadar to abandon this foolishness by depriving them of ketracel-white.

intro.text: "The Founders give us what we need to survive. Children rebelling against their providers must be reminded of what they would lose without them. Without ketracel-white, they will whither and die."

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

screens.text: "While we appreciate the spirit of what you're trying to do, it's entirely unnecessary. The Jem'Hadar are no longer irreplaceable. We have contingency plans should this rebellion spread."

responses.text: "Explain these contingency plans, please."
"No matter what, I have to defend the Xindi."
"So you'd be willing to free the Jem'Hadar?"

screens.text: "Do you? Why not let the Xindi attempt to defend themselves? An audition, as it wereand a great prize awaits the victor."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "It's entirely possible, should they fail to defeat the Hirogen or close this break in the ranks."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Xindi have proven themselves capable of as much loyalty as the Jem'Hadar. Should the Jem'Hadar falter or fall apart, we are confident our Xindi allies could fill the gap."

responses.text: "Only if you take them on as equal partners."
"The Xindi are valuable members of the Federation."
"Such a fate would be about what they deserve."

intro.text: "The nonbelievers have commandeered a ship and plan to bombard a Xindi facility where the Founders are being sheltered. Destroy this ship, and they will learn the price of blasphemy."

screens.text: "We have struck a blow. The rebels now know that turning on the Founders means taking on the entire Federationto say nothing of my wrath and that of the other Firsts."

responses.text: "I only wanted to keep the Xindi safe, not avenge you."
"The Founders don't care about you. They want to replace you."
"I'm glad there are some Jem'Hadar who know their place."

screens.text: "You have done both. You should appreciate the efficiency."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Founders say what they must to keep these Xindi loyal. We are bound by much stronger things than words."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Careful, human. We serve the Founders, not you."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You have spilt blood against these rebels. You may have a share in their ultimate punishment. What should their fate be?"

responses.text: "Let them join the Hirogen if they like. May the best win."
"Imprison them. They can't be allowed to attack the Xindi."
"Execute them. There's no penance for traitors."

screens.text: "The Federation's support has been invaluable. It is from the service records of your Voyager crew that we have crafted the final solution to the Hirogen problem. A viral holoprogram that will turn them all into virtual captives."

responses.text: "How would this weapon work? The Hirogen thrive on living prey."
"Is genocide really necessary? Surely we can negotiate."
"I support this. There's no room in the galaxy for such bloodlust."

screens.text: "The Hirogen are vulnerable to the seductive power of artificial reality. We will use this to our advantage, and cause their hunters to become hopelessly addicted to neuro-adaptive software. Inside the holodeck simulations, they will meet their end, one way or another."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "This was a necessary step. Either the Hirogens prevail in this conflict, or we do. It is not in their nature to change their behavior. They would hunt us to extinction regardless of politics or diplomacy. The only sane choice is to eliminate them before they eliminate us."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "There appears to be much room. But we will deal with the failings of other solids later."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Hirogen are attuned to our every molecule. They have studied us, hunted us, developed an obsession. They will see us comingbut they will not see you. You must deploy the holoprogram for us."

responses.text: "Upload the program to my ship's computers, and we'll set course."
"Very well, but I doubt the Hirogen will fall for this again...."
"The Hirogen may yet be capable of change. We'll see how they react."

quests.name: Going Viral
quests.description: The Dominion believe the Hirogen will destroy themselves via addiction to a viral holoprogram. Unleash it!

intro.text: "We have studied our predators as well. Uploading the holoprogram here, with one of the Hirogen's more reckless packs, will ensure it quickly spreads."

reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

screens.text: "The Dominion prey have proven themselves to be... hunters. We do not all see the merits of this holoprogram, but we are not enough to overcome the Alphas who do. Nevertheless, we will cease hunting the Dominion, if only they will help us to remove it from our own ships."

responses.text: "How do we know this change of heart doesn't amount to deception?"
"Why do you Hirogen deserve mercy, with so much blood on your hands?"
"Would you be prepared to permanently give up the hunt in order to live in peace?"

screens.text: "We do not have codes of honor like your Klingons. But to hunt, we must survive. We cannot survive if we do not do as we promised."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The blood we took was honest, never a result of trickery or politics. Merely predator overcoming prey."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "No. We are the hunt. It is our lives. But we will do what we must to survive this viral program."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Hirogen can contribute nothing to an orderly, peaceful society. If you truly share these values, let our holoprogram lead them to inevitable self-destruction."

responses.text: "I agree. Like all prey, they must adapt or die."
"I won't be party to genocide. I'll help Donik."
"I look forward to continued cooperation between us."

screens.text: "The Alphas have come to respect you as a hunter. But we have suffered too many losses taking the Dominion. Either they submit to the hunt willingly, or we must euthanize them all."

responses.text: "Why not do it anyway? That would be quite the pile of trophies."
"How do you plan to euthanize the entire Dominion?"
"Does this plan of action seem... sporting to you?"

screens.text: "There is no skill involved in executing a helpless beast. It is the thrill of the hunt that drives us, not the death blow."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Various airborne and water-based toxins, when they combine within Founder anatomy, become chemically-active, forming an inert molecule waiting for the final 'trigger' toxin. It has already been tested on a shapeshifter subject... with great success."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "No. But it is the only way to ensure the hunt continues."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Interacting with prey as if it were our intellectual equals is unthinkable to us, and the Dominion would never consent. We instead offer you the chance to present our terms."

responses.text: "What you ask is impossible. No one should voluntarily submit to being hunted."
"I will pass the word to the Dominion, but I believe I can guess their response."
"Genocidal intentions of this kind will earn you many more enemies."

quests.name: Proven Toxicity
quests.description: Help the Hirogen decimate their prey by releasing a biological weapon targeting the Founders, leaders of the Dominion!

intro.text: "Your cooperation with the Hirogen is a clear sign of the Federation's intentions towards us, and we will respond in kind. Deploy this toxinyou will not eliminate us before we have eliminated the Xindi."

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

reward.flavor: Credits are the galaxy's standard currency. Use Credits in the Time Portal to enlist crew members, build items, and more.

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

screens.text: "The Founders have authorized me to... erm, that is... they consent to be hunted. As long as an antidote to this toxin is delivered immediately."

responses.text: "A wise decision. The Dominion may even survive."
"I want you to know I didn't support this move."
"After you threatened to wipe out the Xindi? No chance."

screens.text: "We will do more than survive. We will remember."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You did little to prevent it. I'm not sure of the difference."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We can only hope the Hirogen are more merciful than the Federation."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You respect the hunt. We can ask no more of our allies. You shall never be prey."

responses.text: "That's a relief. Please extend that to the Federation."
"Sure about that? I would be quite a challenge...."
"Any day we avoided genocide is a good day."

screens.text: "A Borg fleet has just dropped out of warp in the Alpha Quadrant... or dropped out of time. These could be Borg from the future, with technology we have no defense against. Our only hope is a swift and severe response."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "All vessels are ordered to converge on the Borg fleet's location and engage before they can make their next move. Any questions, Captain?"

responses.text: "Understood. We'll set course immediately."
"Shouldn't we wait and see if the Borg pose a threat before we fire?"

responses.paraphrase: Wonder what the Borg are up to.
responses.text: "The Borg have come to this quadrant before, and we routed them. Why return?"

screens.text: "Very good. Riker out."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I'll wait and see for the Romulans, the Klingons, the Ferengi, the Dominion... but when it comes to the Borg, I've learned to shoot first."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "If they have some new edge over us. That's reason enough to try again. Let's not waste more time speculating on what it is."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Borg have had their chance at diplomacy, Captain. We may be explorers, but we're defenders too. Defend the Federation."

responses.text: Continue

intro.text: "The line must be drawn here. The Borg must know that whether their arrival was an accident or not, their presence in the Alpha Quadrant will not be tolerated."

screens.text: "That was too easy. I don't like it."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I concur. The Borg made no effort at a coordinated attack. Even now, observing the wreckage of their ship, the rest of the fleet has taken no action, offensive or otherwise."

responses.text: "Are you saying the Borg let us win?"
"Is it possible the Borg don't want to assimilate us?"
"Their despondency is our chance. Let's fire!"

screens.text: "Your vessel should have been outmatched, yet achieved victory with minimal effort. It seems not only possible, but probable."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "If we could offer them nothing. If the cost of assimilation would outweigh the rewards. Could these Borg be from a time so far in the future that humanity's distinctiveness is no longer an attractive prospect?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Many captains would agree, which is why we shouldn't. Never do what the Borg expect."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "All of the remaining Borg ships have not raised their shields. It presents an invitation I believe we should accept, to discover the Borg's true intentions."

responses.text: Continue

quests.name: Into the Lion's Den
quests.description: The Borg did not attempt to defend themselves, and their ship now sits open to visitors. Beam aboard and determine the Borg's status.

intro.text: "The Borg will not engage unless they view you as a threat. Unfortunately, boarding their ship may be the very thing that tips the balance. Use extreme caution."

reward.name: Honor
reward.flavor: Honor is gained by dismissing crew who have served you well, but are ready for reassignment. Redeem in the Time Portal for exclusive crew, special fusion-related items, training programs, and more.

screens.text: "Captain, please... we can't waste time on your human weaknesses, your fear. I need help. My Borg need help."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "One day, over half the Collective simply vanished. Sucked away by temporal anomaly to another place, another time. Severed from the Collective, they surely died quickly, but this is no comfort."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I sustain the Collective, but the Collective sustains me in turn. We are no longer legion. We are no longer enough to keep each other alive. Our objective is no longer perfection, but survival."

responses.paraphrase: Confirm the Borg pose no threat.
responses.text: "So this isn't a trap? You aren't in this quadrant to assimilate us?"

responses.paraphrase: Ask why the Queen is telling you this.
responses.text: "How exactly do you think I can help?"

responses.paraphrase: Declare the Borg got what they deserved.
responses.text: "You reap what you sow. I have no sympathy for you."

screens.text: "We are barely breathing. To take on more would be a last resort, the ends to justify the means."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Thankfully, your Federation is not a dictatorship. You answer to others, and they may feel differently."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You must plead our case to your superiors. You must remind them that our past dealings are not justification for genocide. You must make them see that we Borg are a unique species, worth preserving. You must secure an alliance."

responses.paraphrase: Warn Borg Queen this is a tall order.
responses.text: "I will support your cause. But my word may not be enough."
"What would be the terms of this alliance?"

responses.paraphrase: Refuse to help the Borg Queen.
responses.text: "Actually, genocide seems like the perfect response."

screens.text: "We have contingency plans, though we would prefer not to use them."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Borg and I are symbiotic. Destroy me, and they will follow, without a new nexus. Destroy them, and I will follow--but not without bringing you with me."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Think of it. Cessation of all hostilities. Sharing of technology, information, and an open invitation to be studied. Those who have been assimilated might even be allowed to reconnect with their families."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You could add our technological and cultural distinctiveness to your own. Think of the irony as you travel back to Earth. We will follow."

responses.text: Continue

quests.name: Kicking the Nest
quests.description: In the Borg Queen's weakened condition, she is unable to maintain control of the Borg aboard her vessel, and they are now hostile. Escape the ship!

intro.text: "Even devoting a few moments to speaking with you, instead of controlling the Collective... it was too much. The drones of this ship are now acting on their own power. But I have no doubt you will escape them."

challenges.name: Beam Out Before Shields Go Up

ship.name: Borg Sphere 878
ship.flavor: Commandeered by General Kotok and other rebel Borg members of Unimatrix Zero in 2377.

ship.name: Borg Sphere 878
ship.flavor: Commandeered by General Kotok and other rebel Borg members of Unimatrix Zero in 2377.

screens.text: "You're proposing the Borg join the Federation? That we let them move freely about the Alpha Quadrant? That we trade and deal with beings that have killed or mutilated us on numerous occasions? Do I understand you rightly, Captain?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You see now why I needed you to present my case. He looks at the Collective and sees only death and destruction. I see rebirth, and evolution."

responses.paraphrase: Support ending hostilities at any cost.
responses.text: "Peace is worth many compromises--including forgiveness."

responses.paraphrase: Remind Riker of the strategic advantages.
responses.text: "What's the old saying? 'Keep your enemies close, and the Borg closer?'"

responses.paraphrase: Accuse Borg Queen of false overtures.
responses.text: "You're dying, and you need our help to survive. That's all this is."

screens.text: "If peace was what the Borg really wanted, if they had any concept of what it means. If she saw us as equals and not prey."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Must have been after my time, in an era far enough in the future that Starfleet's completely forgotten what the Borg did to us."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "How fickle is man. You agree to anything to escape my ship, then turn on me when back in the arms of your Federation."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I had a thought your superiors might need more convincing reasons to form an alliance with the Collective. Let me present them to you."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We are the Borg. We must persist. The Collective will grow, by any means necessary."

responses.text: "You said you wanted peace! Yet you continue to assimilate?"
"Restore Counselor Troi immediately, or there can be no peace."
"Wouldn't it be better to help them, Admiral? Before they help themselves?"

screens.text: "No. This was a very targeted operation. I find pressure points more effective than randomization, don't you?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Give me peace, or there can be no Counselor Troi."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "End communications with the Borg vessel. Contact Deanna... Counselor Troi's mother and inform her of what's happened to her daughter."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I'm relieving myself of command. If I don't, I'm liable to bring the full force of Starfleet to bear upon that thing. The next move is yours, Captain, but you'd do well to remember: friends don't take hostages."

responses.paraphrase: Vow to pursue peace with the Borg Queen.
responses.text: "Friendship starts with trust. The Borg Queen will release Troi if we help her."

responses.paraphrase: Vow to avenge Troi upon the Borg Queen.
responses.text: "I'll see the Borg Queen destroyed. Her drones will have no choice after that."

intro.text: "You value your individuality. Know that now you act as any drone might, mindlessly following the orders of your superiors. Destroy me, and destroy the last vestige of what makes you human."

screens.text: "We have a more fluid chain of command these days. We have to, when any officer can vanish to another place and time at a moment's notice."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Still, it's difficult for me to step back and let someone else make the decisions. It makes it easier when that someone is you, and you make the right ones. The Borg are infinitely better off without the Queen."

responses.text: "The Queen was duplicitous. At least the Borg don't lie."
"Are they? The Queen said they couldn't live without her."
"I'm not sure it was worth the cost of all those assimilated."

screens.text: "There are definitely some advantages to being more machine than man. No lies. No feelings."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "How would the Queen know? She might have been an almost immortal intelligence, but none of us truly know what happens after we die."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We called her bluff. Sometimes that pays off, and sometimes it doesn't. No matter what, we can't let ourselves be held hostage by threats."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Any alliance with the Borg Queen was impossible. An alliance with the Borg drones she left behind? That's got a real future. They're innocent victims, and I believe they all still have traces of who they once were."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "First is doing everything we can to support the Collective as they deal with the loss of the Queen. Once they've been stabilized, we can formalize a peace treaty, find them some space within the quadrant, see if they can overcome her influence."

responses.text: "Without the threat of assimilation, I believe we can coexist."
"We've brought the Borg to heel. This is a historic victory."
"Between you and me, I'm going to give the Borg a wide berth."

quests.name: Bearing Up
quests.description: The Borg Queen is holding Starfleet officers hostage with nanoprobes until she receives aid. Dispatch the best and brightest to save the Collective.

intro.text: "Your compassion has always been your greatest weakness. Now it is your greatest strength. It has enabled you to see the wisdom of aiding me. Come, and quickly."

challenges.name: Convince Queen to Link with Fed

ship.name: Borg Sphere 878
ship.flavor: Commandeered by General Kotok and other rebel Borg members of Unimatrix Zero in 2377.

screens.text: "I see why beings such as the one called Q have chosen to trust you. You are surprising. You are the best of your species."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Collective has been stabilized. It is significantly more probable we will survive now. I have remotely deactivated all of the nanoprobes I placed within Starfleet officers. They will not be assimilated."

responses.text: "Now that we've proven we can be trusted, you won't resort to such tactics again."
"If even one of those officers is found to be in less than perfect health...."
"How magnanimous. Forgive me if I don't fall on my knees in gratitude."

screens.text: "We each know the other's capabilities, for better or worse. We start on better footing than even the most intimate of human relationships, wouldn't you say?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I respect your protective instincts, as well as the Admiral's. Something all beings share. Only I have perfected them."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Sarcasm is a tool of the weak. I would respect you more if you told me you despised me flat out."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We may not ever like each other, or understand each other. But neither is required for a successful alliance between our peoples."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Federation may now trade with the Borg in anything they deem valuable, so long as they continue to protect and support us. In turn, we will defend you against your enemies by joining them to our consciousness."

responses.text: "Remember that assimilation goes against the Federation's values."
"If our alliance secures the Federation's safety, it's worth any cost."
"Why does that sound so ominous?"

description: Q hasn't taken an active role in resolving the temporal anomaly crisis, and Starfleet is ready for answers. Get Q's attention, and then begin an epic journey into the Continuum itself.

screens.text: "We're going in circles. Every week, we've got a new fire, and we're no closer to finding the answers. Where the hell is Q?"

responses.text: Continue
"Isn't it possible Q is as lost as we are?"
"For that matter, where are the rest of the Q?"
"If Q doesn't want to talk, we can't make him."

screens.text: "Q was there when this crisis began. He explained it to us. I'm convinced he knows more than he's telling."
"I suppose I'd prefer that, to being at the mercy of another one of his damn games."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I don't know. No one's reported any sightings of them. You'd think Q would be concerned about his son and... his son's mother."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Like hell we can't."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We have contacts in every timeline, every quadrant, and no one's seen hide nor hair of Q. That leaves only one place he could be, only one place that must have more information than he can find here: the Continuum."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We don't know how to reach the Continuum. But Q does. So, first, we need to get his attention. We'll set a trap, with you as the bait."

responses.text: Continue
"If you believe that's our best option, I'm game."
"What's to stop Q from running away again before he answers any questions?"
"If?! Admiral, my crew and I have been essential!"

screens.text: "You'll return to the anomaly, with the same crew, and enter it. If you're as important to this crisis as Q says you are, he'll be forced to respond."
"Nothing. I suppose he considers that part of his charm."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I'm not disputing that. But you are the only one who's been graced--or cursed--with regular contact with Q. For whatever reason, all our other essential officers have not."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Patch us in immediately when Q appears. Either he delivers on that help he's been promising, or he takes us to other Q who can."

responses.text: Continue

intro.text: "Anyone ever told you the definition of insanity? Here's hoping history repeats itself, and brings back our omnipotent guide."

quests.name: Highway to Hell
quests.description: You must now enter the anomaly where it all began, in the hopes of attracting Q's attention. Ensure you have your best at hand!

intro.text: "We're about to enter the unknown. Even after everything, the prospect still excites me. I hope Q doesn't show up too quickly."

reward.flavor: Dilithium is your most valuable asset. Use Dilithium in the Time Portal to acquire valuable crew members, items, and more.

screens.text: "I'm never going to get anything done if I have to keep saving you from your own stupidity. Or is it despondency? Whichever it is, we don't have time for it."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Captain was trying to get to the Continuum to reach you, since you come and go as you please."

responses.text: Continue
"It doesn't matter. You're here now, and that was the point."
"But didn't you take Captain Janeway and her crew there?"
"Then where the hell have you been all this time?"

screens.text: "To think, I offered YOU immortality. What do you think the Continuum is, some extra colorful nebula? It's not a place. You can't reach it."
"You endangered your own lives just to get my attention? I'm flattered."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Oh, Kathy, still talking about our first date."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Notice how your pathetic little moon over there is still circling the Earth? You're welcome."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Allow me to educate you before you warp bow-first into a wall again. Just one snap of my fingers, and you'll be in the Continuum. The snapping is a metaphor, by the way. So is the Continuum."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We want answers, Q, not more party tricks!"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "If it's answers you want, the Continuum has them. Me, I've always been more interested in questions. One, two, three... snap!"

responses.text: Continue

quests.name: Ruinous Staycation
quests.description: Q's attempt to take you to the Continuum has brought you back to Earth instead. Deal with anomalies onboard while Q determines what went wrong.

intro.text: "Your little blue marble. Obviously, this is not the Continuum. Scan for anomalies, or whatever you would do. Give me a moment to shake out my fingers..."

intro.text: "A Borg cube? Uh... I meant to do that. A punishment, for summoning me like some kind of servant. Clean up this mess, and then perhaps we'll continue!"

responses.text: "So what, they've locked you out of the house?"
"Why? What did you do?"
"I'm shocked. Truly."

screens.text: "I've been less than forthright. The Continuum and I... we're not on the best of terms."
"Well... yes, in a manner of speaking."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The Continuum would prefer we all sat in silent judgment over lesser beings. I choose to take a more active role."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Sarcasm doesn't become you, Captain. You'll never wear it as well as I do."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "This isn't the first time this has happened, you know. I've had to figure out other ways of getting inside. A back door, if you will."

responses.text: Continue

quests.name: An Infinite Welcome
quests.description: Q has invited you to enter the Continuum, represented by a door that presumably leads to a house. Enter and explore!

intro.text: "Well, step inside. Welcome to the Continuum."

responses.text: "Q? Is this your true form? An empty book?"
"Were you expecting something else?"
"My universal translator must be broken."

screens.text: "This book... it has nothing to say."
"This is no time for base insults. but... touche."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "A book, owned by god-like beings, sitting in a place of honor atop Olympus itself? Yes, I expected more, Captain."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "The house is deserted. The book is empty. This is English 101!"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Typical. Sticking their heads under the covers instead of engaging with the universe. Let's end their sojourn, shall we? Into the bedroom...."

responses.text: Continue
"Were the Q prisoners in their own home?
"Who or what were your people holding captive here?"
"Can't you just appear as yourself, instead of a talking chain?"

screens.text: "A... chain? And... broken."
"Astute, Captain. And... difficult."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Please, clear your mind of grotesqueries. What could any other being in this universe have that we might want?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Don't you understand? A chain. None of this is a choice, you pathetic little amoeba."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "This was home, for a Q. This is where I--we--were expected to be. Not gallivanting across the universe, playing with ants in the sun."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Now I begin to wonder if our Olympus was really Hades. Fallen gods, being punished for crimes we didn't even know we committed. Has the torture ended? Have the executions begun?"

responses.text: Continue

quests.name: Into the Cave
quests.description: Q has discovered a disturbing metaphor in the empty Continuum--a broken chain. Follow it, and discover what has become of the Q.

intro.text: The broken chain lies before you, floating in space. It says nothing more. Dare you follow it to its end?

reward.name: Dilithium
reward.flavor: Dilithium is your most valuable asset. Use Dilithium in the Time Portal to acquire valuable crew members, items, and more.

screens.text: "I was wondering when you'd return. I knew you were the only one who would."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Quinn! Uh, I mean, Quinn. Have you killed them all? Decided to enforce your mortality on the rest of us?"

responses.text: Continue
"Left? Where has the Continuum gone?"
"You're an old friend of Q's, I take it?"
"Thank you for appearing as a human and not a damned metaphor."

screens.text: "When time is no longer an arrow, mortality loses all permanence. But, when the others left, I could not join them."
"Something like that. I went to your Captain Janeway for asylum. I wanted to die, and the Continuum, represented by Q, wanted me to live. I died."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You say that as if we had another option. You perceive only what your mortal, human mind can handle. If that does not extend beyond a door, a book, a chain... well, wait a few centuries to evolve."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Q does not believe himself a god out of sheer arrogance. We all believed ourselves gods, in total control of the universe and our own destinies. The Continuum left because it discovered the truth.

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "We are part of the universe, not above it. Like gravity, we keep things in order--time, space, motion. Like gravity, remove us, and everything is chaos, floating around together, liable to collide or spin out into nothingness."

responses.text: Continue
"So the Continuum is responsible for the temporal anomaly crisis?"
"Well, call them back! They have a job to do, and the universe is suffering!"
"Q, did you know about this?"

screens.text: "The Continuum finally awoke to this realization. And, having done their duty for millennia, they drew the line here. They left. And until they return, the timelines will remain... well, no longer lines at all."
"Millennia, I said. As slaves to the universe. Your current suffering is great, yes, but is it worth the loss of the Continuum's freedom?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "They spoke often of responsibility. Of not meddling. Little did they know. Little did I know...."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You have the answer you sought. The Q Continuum is responsible, because we choose to no longer be responsible. Chaos now rules the universe. Case in point..."

responses.text: Continue

intro.text: "Man versus himself. The ultimate conflict. Usually it's within... but take away the Q, and it's without. Good luck, Captain. For your sake, I hope you're less than you seem."

screens.text: "These revelations are disturbing. But even more disturbing are the implications. To resolve the temporal anomaly crisis, the Q must be returned to a prison, of sorts."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "I don't buy it. The Q aren't gods. They're just another alien race that happens to have an outsized impact on the material world."

responses.text: Continue
"No, though he did say he can't leave the Continuum himself."
"Not to me. Perhaps something passed between you, Q?"
"The Q have caused nothing but trouble. They can't be part of the solution."

screens.text: "There has to be a way to restore order without enslaving the Continuum. But we'll need to find them first. Quinn didn't mention where they'd gone?"
"Of course he can't. He wants to die. But the rest of the Q are finally, truly, beginning to live."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "If it had, I certainly wouldn't share it with you."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Careful how you speak to the only Q left in the universe, Captain. Or you might find out how troublesome I can be."

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "You say we weren't gods, Admiral. But for millennia, we were slaves to the universe and all its lesser beings. Maintaining an imperceptible order, hearing your prayers, ignoring them. Weren't we gods, in the end?"

responses.text: Continue

screens.text: "Speaking on behalf of my fellow gods, I think we've earned a vacation. A long vacation. Possibly an eternal vacation."

responses.text: Continue
"Now what?"

screens.text: "If you need help again, perhaps one of my past selves will oblige. As for me--one, two, three... snap!"
"First, we find the Q. Then... we fix the universe."

responses.text: Continue
